Legal_Issue: Whether the Applicant met the residency requirement under subsection 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed 1,204 days of presence but had significant absences and lacked corroborating documentation for addresses or family's presence in Canada
Remedy_Requested: Appeal to Federal Court to overturn the Citizenship Judge's decision
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to meet three-year physical presence requirement during the four years preceding application
Assessment_Factor: Application of the Koo qualitative test for residency
Procedural_Issue: Appeal from a Citizenship Judgeâ€™s decision
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant lacked sufficient corroborating evidence to support residency claims
Evidence_Used: Self-reported days of presence, absence records, lack of address verification or family presence documentation
Application_Basis: Accumulation of at least three years of residence in Canada within four years prior to application
Evidence_Assessed: Presence duration, supporting documents for residency, consistency of claims
Relief_Sought: Overturning of the negative decision and approval of citizenship application
Governing_Rule: Koo test for qualitative assessment of residency
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of corroborating documentation for residency and addresses
Outcome: Appeal dismissed; applicant may reapply after re-establishing residency
Cause_Description: Applicant failed to meet residency requirements for citizenship
Evidence_Handling: Insufficient evidence provided and assessed as inadequate by the Citizenship Judge
Evidence_Issues: Lack of reliable and verifiable evidence to prove residency
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge reasonably concluded that the applicant did not meet the required residency threshold based on lack of credible evidence
Decision_Making_Body: Citizenship Judge, reviewed by Federal Court
Evidentiary_Issues: Absence of third-party documentation to verify residence
